details.name: DNA methylation
details.description: a process by which methyl groups are added to DNA, often resulting in gene silencing
details.findings: The article discusses the use of DNA methylation data obtained with EPIC array to identify potential biomarkers for colorectal cancer.
details.notes: The DNA methylation data is publicly available at the Gene Expression Omnibus (GEO) repository.

details.name: Acetone
details.description: A colorless, volatile, and flammable liquid with a characteristic fruity odor, commonly used as a solvent and found in human breath
details.findings: May be considered an adequate cancer biomarker but its concentration in breath changes during activities such as exercising or fasting
details.notes: Its origin can include exogenous factors, especially physical activities and smoking

details.description: A chemical compound used in various industrial applications, found in human breath and potentially related to cancer diagnosis
details.findings: Its origins are unclear, which limits its use as a biomarker for cancer diagnosis
details.notes: Not recommended for use as a biomarker due to unclear origins

details.name: Microbiome
details.description: The community of microorganisms living in a particular habitat, including the human body
details.findings: Was analyzed to identify potential biomarkers for colorectal cancer diagnosis or risk
details.notes: No specific notes mentioned in the article

details.name: Colorectal Cancer Biomarkers
details.description: Molecules that can be used to diagnose, predict, or monitor colorectal cancer
details.findings: Were identified through the analysis of publicly available datasets
details.notes: No specific notes mentioned in the article, generic knowledge only

details.name: Ethyl acetate
details.description: A compound found in natural sources such as fats and fatty oils, waxes, and fruit ethers, also can be produced by the body through various metabolic processes
details.findings: Found in higher amounts in the breath of colorectal cancer patients compared to controls.

details.name: Alkenes
details.description: A type of hydrocarbon that can be produced by the body through oxidative stress and are excreted in the breath due to their low solubility in blood
details.findings: May be related to oxidative stress in colorectal cancer patients.

details.name: Acetone
details.description: A compound produced by the body as a secondary product of lipid peroxidation, often associated with metabolic conditions and ketosis
details.findings: May be elevated in colorectal cancer patients due to high oxidation rate of fatty acids.

details.name: Ethanol
details.description: A compound that can originate from food, alcohol beverages, and metabolism of hydrocarbons by cytochrome p450 enzymes
details.findings: Originates from food, alcohol, and hydrocarbon metabolism in colorectal cancer patients.

details.name: Volatile Organic Compounds (VOCs)
details.description: Compounds that can be found in the breath and are associated with various diseases including colorectal cancer
details.findings: Differ between colorectal cancer patients and controls, suggesting potential for diagnosis.

details.name: T-antigen
details.description: A type of abnormal glycan structure associated with cancer cells
details.findings: Stools from more aggressive lesions may exhibit abnormal immature T-antigen signatures not seen in healthy tissues
details.notes: Explored as a potential biomarker for non-invasive cancer diagnostics

knowledge.subject: T-antigen
knowledge.object: abnormal immature signatures in stools from aggressive lesions

details.name: T-expressing glycoproteoforms
details.description: Proteins with T-antigen glycan structures, potentially associated with cancer
details.findings: Identified as molecular targets shared by more aggressive non-cancerous lesions and cancer
details.notes: Hold promise for future pre-clinical assessment as biomarkers

knowledge.subject: T-expressing glycoproteoforms
knowledge.object: more aggressive non-cancerous lesions and cancer

details.name: Immature glycan signatures
details.description: Abnormal glycan structures associated with cancer cells, lacking full maturation
details.findings: May be present in stools from more aggressive lesions, not seen in healthy tissues

llama3.3:70b-instruct-q8_0/AdcOr.prompt_template:
[BEGIN ARTICLE]:<content></content>
[END ARTICLE]

[INSTRUCTIONS]
Generate list of biomarkers that are one of the main topic iof the article and relates to disease, inflamation or specifically cancer diagnosis or risc. 
List only biomarkers that some findings are in the article. If no findings is in the article about such biomarker, don't include it in the list.
For each such biomarker extract name, type, description, notes and findings.
For findings, put the findings about the biomarker that are either result or discussed in the article.
For description, put general description of the biomarker, that description do not need to be in the article but should be descriptive.
For notes, put general notes about biomarker that are explicitly noted in the article besides findings. 
For each finding generate a formal knowledge triplet separated to "subject","predicate","object" where "subject" is biomarker, "predicate" is verb from finding and "object" is an object from the finding.
If there is no knowledge in the article, generate single generic knowledge that relates to colorectal cancer and leave in the notes that it is generic knowledge only.
Return the response in strict JSON format with the following structure:

[
  { "name": "biomarker name","type":"biomarker type","description":"biomarker description","findings":"brief findings about biomarker in article as one sentence","notes":"additional notes important to biomarker or empty string", "knowledge":[{"subject":"repeated biomarker name","predicate":"some predicate from findings of biomarker","object":"object that relates via predicate to the biomarker" }],
  { "name": "biomarker2 name","type":"biomarker2 type","description":"biomarker2 description","findings":"brief findings about biomarker2 in article as one sentence","notes":"additional notes important to biomarker2 or empty string", "knowledge":[{"subject":"repeated biomarker2 name","predicate":"some predicate from findings of  biomarker2","object":"object that relates via predicate to the biomarker2" }] }
] 

Ensure there is no additional explanation, only return valid JSON.
